The artist relates to his colors like a choir master demanding total intensity from each of his singers, not allowing any of them to rely on the others or be lost in the total sound. For Zim, color is not abstract. It is not a mere pigment. It contains a wealth of meaning. It “speaks.” Its meaning, however, does not stem from the familiar symbolism of “hot” and “cold” or "blood” and “sky.” Blue can be very hot in his paintings, and what is more important, it can have a lot to say beyond its metonymic meanings. His color is a movement, a power, and a blend of sounds, as when the choir joins the orchestra. This is precisely the language of Zim’s tonality of color. Although red is intended to represent the “meaning” of red, Zim searches out the particular shade to express that aspect of the color which he wishes to reveal and convey to the viewer. Consider the dot of red (a roof perhaps?) in this painting: it is as strong as any spot of red amid greens and blues can be, and yet it is very precise, shying away from the violent side of red (which tends toward orange) to ensure the serenity and flow it will create with the greens. Zim’s demands from his choir of colors is equally apparent in his desert scenes, the pale, blinding, arid landscapes of Israel. Even a “weak,” light, indistinct shade somewhere between yellow and gray is ordered to speak, to express itself, to sing with all the intensity it can muster. Figs. 81-88 In the Negev paintings, and especially Negev Water Holes, all from the 1980 s, it seems that beige, ochre, and gray have never been required to be so acute. It is as if Zim is denying the traditional symbolism of the desert as a site of desiccation and barrenness. Instead, he turns it into a blaze of desert colors endowed with an inner abundance. In Negev Water Holes, in line with the explicit subject of the painting, he displays the many layers he finds in the desert landscape: just as the water holes reveal the hidden moisture under a layer of dry sand and stone, so the picture centers around the discovery of hidden blues and reds under a layer of grays and browns. In Zim’s vocabulary of color, red belongs to blue because water symbolizes life within death. Thus red, the symbol of life, joins the blue, representing water, affording it the power of the sharp juxtaposition which produces the cry of life demanded of the color. The painting as a whole declares that reds and blues are hidden under the grays and browns. These concealed hues are not only a dramatic expression of the idea of water holes; they also reveal Zim’s technique for drawing power from his colors. Under the pigments, he “hides” contrasting shades discernible beneath the surface colors. In some cases, they are no more than fine lines, but in others they peek out through cracks and windows carefully left open for them. Zim’s layering technique is part of his search for the power of symbolism. The hidden color is meant to activate the surface shade by means of an internal contrast: a “cold” color never occupies Zim’s canvas as is. He invariably makes it a dramatic presence containing both the hidden and the apparent, restraint and release. Ultimately, a “cold” color appears “hot,” a “quiet” tone makes itself glowingly heard. It does not take a particularly perceptive eye to realize that beauty here is not simply the color contrast. It is a scrap of peacefulness, the red of the roofs and the church steeple, a reminder of both the beautiful world destroyed in the war and the personal and universal childhood of Zim (then still Cymberknopf) in Poland before the extermination of European Jewry. Only someone granted the top drawer of the family commode can know the sense of growing harmoniously out of the past, as does Zim. Only for such a person is creativity not a rebellion and disavowal of the family, but quite the opposite: absolute profound identification with it and a commitment to its values. It was not by chance that the red roofs and church spire of Silesia in winter were a perceivable sign of beauty for Jakob and his brother Natek. It was a piece of landscape familiar to them from the vacations when the family, led by their grandmother, would set out for the country to enjoy the summer days in what Zim repeatedly refers to as “the Garden of Eden." It was in those Polish villages, and sometimes in his close friendships with those same Polish peasants, that Zim experienced his greatest joys as a child, including his bar mitzvah, which was celebrated like a traditional Polish Granie. The abundance (not necessarily material, but rather emotional), the sparkling vitality of his family (especially its lovely and dominant women), and the openness to the world at large and the Polish and European world in particular, are all part of Zim’s concept of “beauty.” From the moment Zim returned to painting in the 1960 s (having worked primarily in graphic design for many years), it became obvious that the symbolism inherent in his “beauty.” the concept derived from the spots of color in his childhood, is, in actuality, the subject of his Fig, 77 canvases. In his still-lifes, landscapes, and boats, such as in Galilee Landscape (early 1980 s), something of the Mediterranean hills is captured on the canvas, but it is no more than contours, and they too make no attempt to present an accurate depiction of the landscape. Instead, they are there merely to remind the viewer of the world behind the painting to which it is referring. Beyond this, the painting speaks for itself, and it is primarily the colors that have something to say. Zim seemingly extracts the colors from the landscape, squeezing them out of it. There is something almost obsessive about the power of the color he demands from his medium: he commands it to express, with virtually stunning potency, that which is hidden within the objects and landscapes. WHEN COLORS SPEAK

Ariel Hirschfeld Before any attempt at an understanding or leisurely observation of Zim’s paintings, the viewer is first inundated by color; a strong stream of color seems to wash over us, bursting forth from the canvas. Each tone, even the quietest grays - to say nothing of the bold reds, greens, and blues - stands out more clearly on the canvas than in any natural context. Zim places them side by side so that one accentuates the other, “drawing it out,” activating it, and brushing off the cobwebs of the obvious. His colors are his subjects. They are not “the colors of things” (the red of poppies or blood, the blue of the sea or sky), but the colors of colors. He seeks to galvanize the red tones so that from within the red, something is said that has never been said before, as if the treasure troves of the different reds held stifled messages, successions of meaning just waiting for the moment to be given expression. The extraordinary vitality and joyous verve with which the colors come together on Zim’s canvases are undoubtedly the products of his discovery of color as a child in Sosnowiec, the city he depicts so well in his memoirs: the lively, feverishly busy world of his family home at 18 Targowa St., provided for by the income from his father’s house and sign painting. The spots of paint on his father’s work clothes never looked like stains to Zim, but like the cheerful expressions of life, his first encounter with “beauty.” The same was true for the spots of light and color from the glass factory next door to the Cymberknopf’s; the light from the furnaces dancing on the colorful glass bubbles taking shape in the hands of the glassblowers. These are more than mere memories for Zim: they are heady sights that dyed his whole world and established his future connection with art and color. They also established the meaning of color for him, as well as his fascination with its power. Color is home, that home, the place which was a home in every essential and fateful sense of the term: supportive, welcoming, comforting, constructive, suffused with emotion and value. It was a crowded house, home to several generations at once, but one in which each individual had his or her own place. There is no better expression of Jakob’s personal cherished space in his family home than the large cabinet, the “commode” to which he devotes a special chapter in his memoirs. Figs. 3-4 The commode became a symbol for him of the essential family spirit. Its presence in the house was associated with the figure of his grandmother, who insisted it not be replaced by a newer piece of furniture. It held the family treasures, from which Zim became acquainted with the Jewish artists Israels, Gottlieb, Hirschenberg, Struck, Lilien, and Steinhardt. At Passover in the Spring, however, it became a different sort of symbol. Its drawers were emptied to make room for the dozens of eggs needed for the holiday dishes. Only the daily reality of the home could turn a single piece of furniture into such a powerful icon of life, alternately containing the symbols of culture and fertility: paintings and eggs. And what is the called-for image that remains from a reservoir of illusive sights and experiences from another place and another time; the image that would express (with a private measure of accuracy) the gaps and bridges between present and latent, between substantial and blurred, between a thing from the past and a thing in the present; the image that often (mainly during the past decade) takes upon itself the verdict of the past? We are clearly faced with a dialectical interplay where the past and the present can be but mutually influenced, possibly even mutually conditioned. Thus, Zim's image contains both, whether concurrently or intermittently. It is always committed to an expression that is at once spontaneous and precise. Zim’s choices - the statement, the concealment, the avoidance, the transfer of the eyesight onto the paper or canvas through a quick etude performed vis-a-vis nature, the construction of the image as an encounter between form and symbols in the service of some metaphor - belong in the broader field of modernism. Zim the artist, however, who is. as aforesaid, not bound by any ideology, tiptoes through that field as if through raindrops. The conflicts always remain in the background, between manual work and the wisdom of the heart. Aim Liiski once justly placed Zim’s choices between the options introduced by Ardon and Zaritsky, between punctilious dexterity on the one hand and free offhandedness on the other. To this I would like to add: between Zaritsky’s sensory-tactile light and Ardon’s “inner,” graphic light. A similar degree of accuracy, of careful consideration that marks the private commitment, is also discernible in the other facet of Zim’s work, an inkling of which is presented in this book: the work of the graphic artist. Zim devoted the bulk of his time, for many years, to practical graphics and teaching, not only as a means of livelihood but as a vocation, a calling. This is a significant aspect in the multi-faceted personality of an artist who was told by Ardon that “man cannot live on art alone these days.” But I would like to return to Zim the painter. His statement, throughout its incarnations, derives its validity from its poetic nature, and it is this sense of poetry that informs its transformations - from the concrete to the hidden and veiled, from the etude (entirely taking place vis-a-vis Nature) to the painting (wholly executed in front of the canvas). Thus I would like to conclude with an excerpt from a poem by Israel Eliraz: I bend the brims / of the lake hidden / within the visible and pass / the green finger of thought / over them / until a shape is formed / which while partial / is nevertheless ravishing and real and 1 / can take it home / like a violin under the infinite / arm of memory / Israel Eliraz, “Three Days by the Water,” Tiyyul [Excursion] (Tel Aviv; Sifriyat Poalim, 1987), p. 78 (Hebrew].
REFLECTIONS UPON THE COMMENCEMENT OF A BOOK

Yona Fischer We are standing on the threshold of a book endeavoring to expose (expose, rather than sum up) a life’s work to the public eye; a book that sets out to lay bare the motivations and circumstances of an oeuvre, its processes and metamorphoses, the very rudiments of its private nature, rather than locate it within the broader contexts of place and time, notions that can subordinate it to the general practice in terms of belonging, participation, even in terms of avoidance or denial. Jakob Zim’s art spans many decades. If it has not received befitting critical attention, it is due to its quintessentially private nature, which is, for Zim, a sign (or an outcome) of his loyalty to principles of creation whose traces will guide us through a wealth of contents and themes, styles and mindsets. The privateness underlying Zim’s work, its nearly puritanical distinction from the general scene, its avoidance of affiliation with any of the trends or tendencies that have outlined the times and processes of local art - all these may also be due to another reason: the total lack of any so-called “ideology” in his painting, which is wholly concerned with the formulation of the image as an exact tone. In terms of the here - Zim’s painting belongs and does not belong at one and the same time. It is painting that originated there and was effaced there, only to resurface here under unique circumstances. Concurrently, it is painting that sprouted and crystallized here, as if its goal had always been to pave the way for an encounter with the there', painting that preserves painterly traditions and sensibilities of another place and other times (his times, not the times of art). Perhaps one should say that these have been obscured in it by the imperatives of other impulses - the immediate drives of a present, the desire to paint that which appears before the hungry eye, in sensory and artistic modes that could only have emerged here. Finally, Zim’s privateness lies in the unique encounter between there and here, between then and now, between concealed and covert on the one hand and revealed and overt on the other - juxtapositions that lent his painting meanings that have accumulated in the transition from the private to the public, in the oscillation between eyesight and the wisdom of the heart. Zim’s insights into the times of there and here are the type of insights a man harnesses for his own use, for himself alone, not for others. In no way does this reduce the responsibility or lessen the awareness of the need for accuracy. On the contrary: accuracy of expression underlies the very choice between visible and apt - but also between the need for the dim gray that serves as a screen of sorts, and the profusion of color which is, for him, a distinctive sign of visibility. Zim yearns for a fusion between spontaneity, which he perceives as the weapon of sensitivity and attentiveness to the heart’s desires, and skepticism - its restraining companion, which ultimately sets wisdom free; wisdom that calls upon him to criticize, consider, and ask the ultimate question: What is the image? To what extent is it present in-and-of-itself? To what extent is it formulated as an adequate statement (which at the same time avoids redundancy)? For Ruti

Zim’s paintings represent the meeting point of two deeply held attitudes or two essentials that exist side by side in dialectical tension: the yearning for the absolute, for values beyond the “self’, perhaps even beyond history itself, a desire expressed in a move toward the abstract; and the tacit commitment to a time and place, the duty to nurture and maintain the connection between art and life. It is the tension between these two essentials that endows his work with a concrete/universal depth, and enables it to embrace the absolute and abstract in the down-toearth landscapes of the ephemeral and particular. As the conflict between the two opposite poles is never resolved, the dialectic between the eye that sees and the hand that paints remains intact, and is the fulcrum of the drive and artistic power of Jakob Zim’s paintings.
